description: [Status: stable] [Name: runtime-string-union] [Message: Invalid string member in X | Y-style union type] What it does Checks for the presence of string literals in X | Y-style union types. Why is this bad? PEP 604 introduced a new syntax for union type annotations based on the | operator. While Python's type annotations can typically be wrapped in strings to avoid runtime evaluation, the use of a string member within an X | Y-style union type will cause a runtime error. Instead, remove the quotes, wrap the entire union in quotes, or use from __future__ import annotations to disable runtime evaluation of annotations entirely. Example var: "Foo" | None class Foo: ... Use instead: from __future__ import annotations var: Foo | None class Foo: ... Or, extend the quotes to include the entire union: var: "Foo | None" class Foo: ...
